bibl.title: Letter from Douglas R. Dodge to Philip Showalter Hench, January 10, 1942

div1.p: Dodge, George Carroll's cousin, will ask Carroll to see Hench. He discusses George Carroll's personality.

div1.head: Letter from Douglas R. Dodge to Philip Showalter Hench, January 10, 1942

January 10, 1942
Philip S. Hench, M.D.,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I was very happy to receive your letter concerning your work
on Yellow Fever and your reprint. I am sorry that I am unable
to say exactly why Mr. Carroll is so reticent about seeing you.
I do not know Mr. Carroll very well having only seen him a
few times when I was in school in Baltimore, however I do know
that he has a rather peculiar, withdrawn type of personality and
is not at all given to hero-worship. When his mother was alive
she talked so constantly about Doctor Carroll and his works
that I feel this may be one of the reasons why he does not want
the matter brought up again. The whole matter was very embar-
rassing to him. However, at your request I am writing Mr.
Carroll explaining the situation and asking as a favor to me
if he would interview you at a time that you might set during
your sojourn in Washington.

I wish to thank you also for your offer to give me one of the
pictures but this will not be necessary as the John Wyeth Com-
pany has already presented me with one.

If I am ever back your way I will certainly look forward to
making your acquaintance and should you come to California be
sure to drop in to see Carlos and me.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Douglas R. Dodge M. D. DRD-es
Carroll sister
Mrs McElwag
Mrs Buschler
